job_title: Assistant Director of Development in Iowa City, IA
pros: Work from home, plus delta training, strong retirement plan and healthcare benefits, good vacation and sick pay. There is a lot of opportunity to grow your career.
cons: Team culture can matter a lot.

pros: The pay is better than almost all jobs the University offers.  While the management can be annoying, they are students and former callers who can connect with their employees.  They are almost always supportive and even when you screw up treat you fair and with respect.
cons: Maturity level of some supervisors can be a little distracting or annoying.  Program Assistants who have had the job for a while tend to think they are more that fifty cents an hour better than the callers.  Treat employees differently based on their personal lives with employees out of work.  There is always a veil over the real reason things are done the way they are.

job_title: Associate Director in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Flexible schedule
Flexible options regarding travel

cons:
Lacked a team environment
Managers are not true "managers", they are just employees who have been there for a decade.
Good ol' boys club
Tenure trumps talent
Ideas presented to leadership are not taken as ways to improve the organization, rather, speaking disparagingly against the company

review_title: This was a great place to work.
job_title: Telefund Specialist in Iowa City, IA
pros: This was a great work environment. I looked forward to going to work and being able to connect with alumni on a nightly basis.
cons: Hours are 5-9 p.m. for telefund specialist. I wish the hours were more flexible in order to get more hours to students who want them while still working around their schedule.
